terrain.surface: Gravel roads through Colorado countryside. Moderate elevation with rolling scenery.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Local Colorado event. Rolling terrain with good access, moderate costs, and small local field.

biased_opinion.summary: Grassroots Gravel is a local event in Colorado—rolling terrain with moderate elevation. The Colorado countryside is scenic, but the small local field and limited organization keep it in Tier 4.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid local Colorado gravel race. Worth it for Colorado/Mountain West riders. Not worth traveling for.

final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're local to Colorado—yes, it's solid. If you're traveling—skip it.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better Colorado races: Gravel Worlds, SBT GRVL, Leadville.

logistics.food: Pueblo has full dining options. Stock nutrition.

non_negotiables.why: Colorado rolling terrain requires sustained effort.

logistics.explanation: Aaron Sudduth won the 40-mile overall while Boudewijn Van Werven claimed second in a bunch sprint against Subaru-Groove and Cinch Cycling racers, showing the race executes competitive timing and results. Friday expo and Saturday racing keeps it simple, though they're still finalizing lodging partnerships for 2026.

length.explanation: Four distances from 15 miles (The Mild, 600ft gain) up to 113 miles (The Whole, 7,900ft gain) with tactical racing possible - Van Werven's bunch sprint finish on the 75-miler proves the courses support pack dynamics, not just solo suffering. Similar distance to Crusher in the Tushar.

technicality.explanation: The Twelvemile climb hits 16% grades briefly but riders report 'shockingly good' surface quality ranging from 'fine champagne goodness to moderate classic gravel.' As one rider noted, 'the terrain and texture don't present a typical technical challenge.' Less technical than The Mid South.

elevation.explanation: The Twelvemile climb delivers 3,400 feet of gain over 11 miles at 5.7% average grade, starting at 6,275 feet and summiting at 9,585 feet. One rider warns: 'Don't get fooled' by occasional flat sections - 'You're not done yet.' Similar elevation profile to Gravel Worlds.

climate.explanation: Historical weather data shows average highs of 73°F and lows of 45°F, with a 10% chance of rain on any given day, and gusts reaching 32 mph. October in Pueblo means fall weather at elevation with potential temperature swings. The race starts downtown at Main Street and Alan Hamel Avenue, providing some urban shelter before heading into open country exposure. More weather exposure than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

altitude.explanation: Starting around 6,275 feet in Pueblo and climbing to 9,585 feet on Twelvemile creates noticeable altitude impact. As one rider described breathing 'deep the mountain air, rich with ponderosa,' the elevation is present but manageable for most fitness levels. Modest altitude compared to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

adventure.explanation: One rider captured the Twelvemile experience: 'There's no way this is a Colorado State Highway,' surrounded by 'towering, rusty-orange pillars crowned in green' with views of the Wet Mountain Range. It's Colorado's last unpaved state highway.

prestige.explanation: George York finished 2nd in the 75-mile, 60+ age group and Cory Martin placed 5th in his first gravel race, showing solid regional participation. However, it's still Adam Davidson's local event replacing Gravel Locos without established national recognition.

race_quality.explanation: The event attracted competitive riders like Van Werven sprinting against Subaru-Groove and Cinch Cycling teams, with 'industry-leading timing' and full support including Solar Roast Coffee greeting riders at the Twelvemile summit.

experience.explanation: Friday night concert features Los Mocochetes and The Savage Blush, Saturday afterparty with international drum & bass DJ BC#9. The two-day outdoor expo and downtown Pueblo start/finish location create a festival atmosphere beyond just riding.

community.explanation: Adam Davidson describes hearing 'the friendliest event I've ever been to' frequently from participants. The race draws 'internationally recognized professional cyclists' alongside 'local youth, first-time racers, and everyone in-between.'

field_depth.explanation: Elite riders like Sudduth, Van Werven, and York placed well in 2024, with Martin finishing 5th despite it being his first gravel race. Competitive sprints between sponsored teams show regional depth but limited national elite participation. Thinner field than Ouray Gravel Grinder. As Boudewijn Van Werven puts it: "claimed second in the 75-miler from a bunch sprint against several Subaru-Groove and Cinch Cycling racers"

value.explanation: The race offers four distance options from 15 to 113 miles with full support including aid stations, SAG vehicles, and coffee at the summit. Proceeds support multiple nonprofits and the Ride Together Grant provides 10 free entries annually.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs $75-100. Pueblo location keeps accommodation costs reasonable compared to resort towns, though they're still finalizing 2026 lodging partnerships. Denver International Airport is 110 miles away, adding drive time and gas costs to your weekend budget. Higher total cost than Badlands.

primary.name: Specialized Pathfinder Pro
primary.why: Fast center, grippy edges. The modern all-rounder benchmark.

primary.name: Panaracer GravelKing SK
primary.why: Affordable all-rounder. Light knobs add grip without killing speed.

primary.name: Vittoria Terreno Mix
primary.why: Graphene versatility. Mixed-terrain grip with reasonable rolling speed.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners
